entry.title: The Discrete Fourier Transform and Fast Fourier Transform
entry.summary: We analyze 1 the theoretical properties of both the Discrete Fourier Transform (DFT) and the optimized Fast Fourier Transform (FFT), and estimate their algorithmic complexity. Discrete Fourier Transform Theory The DFT converts a finite-length time-domain signal into its frequency-domain representation. For an input signal \(x[n]\) of length \(N\), where \(0 \le n \le N-1\), the DFT is defined as: \[ X[k] = \sum_{n=0}^{N-1} x[n]\, W_N^{kn}, \quad 0 \le k \le N-1 \label{eq:DFT} \]

entry.title: My First Post
entry.summary: This is a post about latex. An equation: \[\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-x^2} dx\]. inline example: \(\sum_{i = 0}^N 2i = y\) One overbrace: \[{a}^{b} - \overbrace{c}^{d}\] Two overbraces: \[\underbrace{a}_{b} - \underbrace{c}_{d}\] None of these below works properly: \[ \begin{aligned} equation &= 16 \\ other &= 26 + 13 \end{aligned} \] \[ \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} \]
